parts:
Short answer:

- **(i) Yes.** That is exactly how the topology generated by a sub-basis is defined.
- **(ii) No, in general.** Doing “unions first, then finite intersections” does **not** produce all opens.
- **(iii) If your iteration includes at least one round of finite intersections followed by a round of arbitrary unions, you’ve already reached the generated topology; no transfinite iteration is needed.** Alternating further does not add anything.

---

### Why (i) works
Let \(S\) be a sub-basis on \(X\). The **standard construction** is:
\[
\mathcal{B} \;=\; \{\text{finite intersections of members of } S\}\quad(\text{include the empty intersection }=X),
\]
and then take
\[
\mathcal{T} \;=\; \{\text{arbitrary unions of members of }\mathcal{B}\}.
\]
\(\mathcal{B}\) is a basis, and \(\mathcal{T}\) is the smallest topology containing \(S\). So (i) gives exactly the generated topology in one pass.

### Why (ii) fails (in general)
Let \(U_1\) be all arbitrary unions of members of \(S\), and then close under **finite intersections**. Every set you get this way can be rewritten (by distributing finite intersections over unions)
\[
\bigcap_{k=1}^n \left(\bigcup_{i\in I_k} S_{k,i}\right)
\;=\;
\bigcup_{(i_1,\dots,i_n)\in I_1\times\cdots\times I_n}
\bigcap_{k=1}^n S_{k,i_k},
\]
so each such set is **a union of finite intersections of subbasic sets**—i.e. it lies in the topology from (i). Thus (ii) produces a **subset** of the correct topology.

But it can be strictly smaller. A concrete example on \(\mathbb{R}\): take the usual sub-basis
\[
S=\{(-\infty,a):a\in\mathbb{R}\}\cup\{(a,\infty):a\in\mathbb{R}\}.
\]
- Arbitrary unions of subbasic rays are either \(\emptyset\), \(\mathbb{R}\), a single ray, or the complement of a single closed interval.
- Finite intersections of those are complements of **finite unions** of closed intervals—i.e. opens with only **finitely many** connected components.
- However, many open sets (e.g. \(\bigcup_{m\in\mathbb{Z}}(m,m+\tfrac12)\)) have **infinitely many** components and are open in the standard topology. These do **not** arise from (ii).

Hence (ii) does not, in general, generate all open sets.

### About (iii) (iterating)
If you **alternate** the two closure operations, you stabilize quickly:
- Starting from \(S\), first take finite intersections (basis stage), then arbitrary unions—this already gives the generated topology \(\mathcal{T}\).
- If you instead start with unions (as in (ii)) and then take finite intersections, you generally get a proper subset; but **one more** “arbitrary unions” step gets you back up to \(\mathcal{T}\).
- No transfinite/“possibly infinite” iteration is required: two steps (finite intersections → arbitrary unions) suffice, and further alternation does not add new sets.

---

### Takeaway
Use **(i)**. If you ever do (ii), follow it by another “arbitrary unions” step to recover the same result as (i). Iterating beyond that is unnecessary.

parts:
Let \(X\) be a set and \(S\subseteq\mathcal P(X)\) a sub-basis.  
Define
\[
\mathcal B \;=\; \Bigl\{\;\bigcap_{k=1}^n U_k \;:\; n\in\mathbb N,\; U_k\in S\Bigr\}\cup\{X\}
\]
(i.e. all **finite** intersections of members of \(S\), with the empty intersection taken to be \(X\)).  
Let
\[
\mathcal T_S \;=\; \Bigl\{\;\bigcup_{\alpha\in A} B_\alpha \;:\; B_\alpha\in \mathcal B\Bigr\}
\]
(i.e. all **arbitrary** unions of members of \(\mathcal B\)).

I will prove that \(\mathcal T_S\) is the **smallest** topology on \(X\) that contains \(S\). This establishes that construction (i) “finite intersections, then arbitrary unions” yields exactly the topology generated by \(S\).

# 1) \(\mathcal B\) is a basis
To show \(\mathcal B\) is a basis on \(X\) we need:

**(B1) Covering.** \(\bigcup \mathcal B = X\).  
This holds because \(X\in\mathcal B\) (empty intersection), so certainly \(\bigcup\mathcal B\supseteq X\).  
(If you prefer the convention “a sub-basis covers \(X\)”, then \(\bigcup S=X\) and hence \(\bigcup\mathcal B\supseteq \bigcup S=X\) also works.)

**(B2) Refinement.** If \(x\in B_1\cap B_2\) with \(B_1,B_2\in\mathcal B\), then there exists \(B_3\in\mathcal B\) such that \(x\in B_3\subseteq B_1\cap B_2\).  
Write \(B_1=\bigcap_{i=1}^m U_i\) and \(B_2=\bigcap_{j=1}^n V_j\) with \(U_i,V_j\in S\). Then
\[
B_1\cap B_2 \;=\; \bigcap_{i=1}^m U_i \;\cap\; \bigcap_{j=1}^n V_j,
\]
a finite intersection of members of \(S\), hence an element of \(\mathcal B\). Taking \(B_3:=B_1\cap B_2\) gives the desired refinement.

Thus \(\mathcal B\) is a basis. By the standard basis construction, the sets that are arbitrary unions of elements of \(\mathcal B\) form a topology—this is precisely \(\mathcal T_S\). Hence \(\mathcal T_S\) is a topology on \(X\).

# 2) \(S\subseteq \mathcal T_S\)
Each \(U\in S\) is itself a finite intersection (with one factor), so \(U\in\mathcal B\subseteq\mathcal T_S\). Therefore \(\mathcal T_S\) is a topology **containing** \(S\).

# 3) Minimality: \(\mathcal T_S\) is the smallest topology containing \(S\)
Let \(\mathcal T\) be any topology on \(X\) with \(S\subseteq \mathcal T\). Because \(\mathcal T\) is a topology it is closed under **finite intersections**; hence every finite intersection of members of \(S\) lies in \(\mathcal T\). Therefore \(\mathcal B\subseteq \mathcal T\). Since \(\mathcal T\) is also closed under **arbitrary unions**, every union of members of \(\mathcal B\) lies in \(\mathcal T\); that is, \(\mathcal T_S\subseteq \mathcal T\).

Because \(\mathcal T\) was arbitrary among topologies containing \(S\), it follows that \(\mathcal T_S\) is contained in **every** such topology. Combined with step 2, this shows \(\mathcal T_S\) is exactly the **intersection of all topologies containing \(S\)**—i.e. the topology **generated by \(S\)**.

---

## Conclusion
Starting from a sub-basis \(S\), taking **all finite intersections** (to form \(\mathcal B\)) and then **all arbitrary unions** (to form \(\mathcal T_S\)) yields a topology; it contains \(S\) and is contained in any topology that contains \(S\). Hence construction (i) produces precisely the topology generated by \(S\).

parts:
Mostly yes—**if you “constructively” build** the \(\sigma\)-algebra from a generating family by repeatedly closing under complements and countable unions, you generally need **transfinite (countable-ordinal–length) iteration**. There is **no fixed finite number of rounds** that suffices in general.

Here’s a clean way to see it.

# A canonical transfinite construction
Let \(X\) be a set and \(\mathcal A\subseteq\mathcal P(X)\). Define an operator \(\mathsf C\) on families of sets by
\[
\mathsf C(\mathcal F):=\text{ the smallest family containing }\mathcal F\text{ that is closed under complements and countable unions}.
\]
Now build an increasing sequence \((\mathcal A^{(\alpha)})_{\alpha}\) by transfinite recursion:
- \(\mathcal A^{(0)} := \mathcal A \cup \{\varnothing,X\}\).
- \(\mathcal A^{(\alpha+1)} := \mathsf C(\mathcal A^{(\alpha)})\).
- For limit ordinals \(\lambda\), set \(\mathcal A^{(\lambda)} := \bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}\mathcal A^{(\beta)}\).

Then
\[
\sigma(\mathcal A) \;=\; \bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\mathcal A^{(\alpha)}.
\]
It’s immediate that the right-hand side is a \(\sigma\)-algebra containing \(\mathcal A\); minimality is by construction (any \(\sigma\)-algebra containing \(\mathcal A\) contains each stage, hence their union).

# Why transfinite stages are genuinely needed
For many natural examples, **no finite stage** (indeed, no single **countable** stage index \(\alpha\) that works uniformly) captures everything.

- Take \(X=\mathbb R\) with \(\mathcal A\) the open sets. The \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\sigma(\mathcal A)\) is the **Borel \(\sigma\)-algebra**. The classical **Borel hierarchy** \((\mathbf\Sigma^0_\alpha,\mathbf\Pi^0_\alpha)\) stratifies Borel sets by alternating **countable unions** and **complements** along **countable ordinals** \(\alpha\):
  - \(\mathbf\Sigma^0_1\) = open, \(\mathbf\Pi^0_1\) = closed.
  - \(\mathbf\Sigma^0_2\) = countable unions of closed (i.e., \(F_\sigma\)), \(\mathbf\Pi^0_2\) = countable intersections of open (i.e., \(G_\delta\)).
  - Continue by transfinite alternation for \(\alpha<\omega_1\).
  - **Strictness:** For every countable \(\alpha\), there exist Borel sets that first appear at level \(\alpha\). Consequently,
    \[
    \mathcal B(\mathbb R)=\bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\mathbf\Sigma^0_\alpha
    \]
    and you **cannot stop** at any fixed finite (or even any single predetermined countable) stage and already have all Borel sets.
    
Thus, if your procedure is “start from opens and keep closing under countable unions/complements in stages,” you need **transfinite iteration through all countable ordinals** to guarantee you’ve reached every Borel set.

# Important qualifications
- This does **not** mean you can’t *define* \(\sigma(\mathcal A)\) in one shot: by definition,
  \[
  \sigma(\mathcal A)=\bigcap\{\mathcal S:\mathcal S\text{ is a }\sigma\text{-algebra and }\mathcal A\subseteq\mathcal S\}.
  \]
  The transfinite construction is about an **explicit build-up** via closure operations, not about existence.

- For a **specific** generated \(\sigma\)-algebra, the iteration **stops at some countable stage** (because each individual Borel set has a countable rank). If \(\mathcal A\) is **countable**, the resulting \(\sigma(\mathcal A)\) is at most countable and the construction stabilizes by some countable ordinal (depending on \(\mathcal A\)); but there is **no uniform finite bound** that works for all \(\mathcal A\).

- If you start from an **algebra** \(\mathcal A\) (closed under finite unions and complements), the **monotone class theorem** can sometimes give a more economical route: \(\sigma(\mathcal A)\) equals the monotone class generated by \(\mathcal A\). This still corresponds, in effect, to a transfinite closure process; it just packages the alternation of operations differently.

---

**Bottom line:** Unlike the topology-from-subbasis case (one pass: finite intersections → arbitrary unions), constructing a \(\sigma\)-algebra from a generating family by alternating countable unions and complements can genuinely require **transfinite (countable-ordinal) many stages**. The Borel hierarchy on \(\mathbb R\) is the standard witness.

parts:
Here’s a completely explicit, “from S upward” construction that does not assume any topology.

# Setup

Let \(X\) be any **uncountable** set and \(S\subseteq\mathcal P(X)\) nonempty.  
Write \(A^c:=X\setminus A\).

Define an increasing transfinite sequence \(\{\mathcal F_\alpha\}_{\alpha}\subseteq\mathcal P(\mathcal P(X))\) by:

**Stage 0.**
\[
\mathcal F_0 \;:=\; S\cup\{\varnothing,X\}.
\]

**Successor stage \(\alpha\mapsto\alpha+1\).** Close \(\mathcal F_\alpha\) under **one round** of the two σ–operations, *applied only to sets already in \(\mathcal F_\alpha\)*:
\[
\mathcal F_{\alpha+1}
\;:=\;
\mathcal F_\alpha
\;\cup\;
\{A^c:A\in\mathcal F_\alpha\}
\;\cup\;
\Bigl\{\textstyle\bigcup_{n\in\mathbb N} A_n : A_n\in\mathcal F_\alpha\ \forall n\Bigr\}.
\]

**Limit stage \(\lambda\) (nonzero limit ordinal).**
\[
\mathcal F_\lambda \;:=\; \bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}\mathcal F_\beta.
\]

Finally, set
\[
\sigma(S)\;:=\; \bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\mathcal F_\alpha,
\]
where \(\omega_1\) is the first uncountable ordinal.

---

## Why this equals the σ–algebra generated by \(S\)

1) **\(\sigma(S)\) is a σ–algebra.**

- **Contains \(\varnothing,X\)** by construction, and is clearly upward closed in \(\alpha\).

- **Closed under complements.** If \(A\in\sigma(S)\), choose \(\alpha\) with \(A\in\mathcal F_\alpha\). Then \(A^c\in\mathcal F_{\alpha+1}\subseteq\sigma(S)\).

- **Closed under countable unions.** If \(A_n\in\sigma(S)\), pick \(\alpha_n\) with \(A_n\in\mathcal F_{\alpha_n}\). Let \(\alpha:=\sup_n \alpha_n\) (still a **countable** ordinal). Then every \(A_n\in\mathcal F_\alpha\), so \(\bigcup_n A_n\in\mathcal F_{\alpha+1}\subseteq\sigma(S)\).

Thus \(\sigma(S)\) is a σ–algebra.

2) **Minimality.** Let \(\mathcal S\) be any σ–algebra with \(S\subseteq\mathcal S\). Then \(\mathcal F_0\subseteq\mathcal S\). If \(\mathcal F_\alpha\subseteq\mathcal S\), closure of \(\mathcal S\) under complements and countable unions gives \(\mathcal F_{\alpha+1}\subseteq\mathcal S\); for limit \(\lambda\), the union is also contained. By transfinite induction, \(\mathcal F_\alpha\subseteq\mathcal S\) for all \(\alpha\), hence \(\sigma(S)\subseteq\mathcal S\). Therefore \(\sigma(S)\) is exactly **the** σ–algebra generated by \(S\).

---

## A useful viewpoint: ranks (Borel-style hierarchy relative to \(S\))

Define classes \(\Sigma^S_\alpha,\Pi^S_\alpha\) for countable ordinals \(\alpha\) by:
- \(\Sigma^S_1\) = all **countable unions** of sets from \(S\cup\{\varnothing\}\).
- \(\Pi^S_\alpha\) = complements of \(\Sigma^S_\alpha\).
- \(\Sigma^S_{\alpha+1}\) = countable unions of \(\Pi^S_\alpha\).
- For limit \(\lambda\): \(\Sigma^S_\lambda=\bigcup_{\alpha<\lambda}\Sigma^S_\alpha\).

Then
\[
\sigma(S)=\bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\Sigma^S_\alpha=\bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\Pi^S_\alpha.
\]
Every \(A\in\sigma(S)\) has a **countable rank**: the least \(\alpha<\omega_1\) with \(A\in\Sigma^S_\alpha\cup\Pi^S_\alpha\).

This rephrases the same construction but separates “union-stages” and “complement-stages.” It makes clear why we stop at \(\omega_1\): **any** expression built using *countably many* unions and complements has a **countable** syntactic depth.

---

## How many stages are actually needed?

Define the **closure index**
\[
\theta(S):=\min\{\alpha\le\omega_1:\ \mathcal F_\alpha \text{ is a σ–algebra}\}.
\]
General facts:

- **Uniform upper bound:** \(\theta(S)\le \omega_1\) for every \(X,S\).  
  (Reason: in the proof of σ–closure above we only ever needed to take sups of **countably** many stage indices, which remain \(<\omega_1\).)

- **No finite bound in general:** There are natural \(S\) for which \(\theta(S)\) is **not** finite and indeed reaches the maximum \(\omega_1\).  
  Example: take \(X=\mathbb R\) and let \(S\) be a countable base for the open sets (e.g. rational open intervals). The generated σ–algebra is the Borel σ–algebra, whose hierarchy is strict at every countable level; no single finite (or even fixed countable) level suffices.

- **Small \(S\) does not imply small \(\theta(S)\):** In the example above, \(S\) is **countable** yet \(\theta(S)=\omega_1\).

- **Large \(S\) does not force large \(\theta(S)\):** If \(S\) is already an **algebra** (closed under finite unions and complements), then \(\theta(S)=1\): one successor step adds all countable unions, and you’re done. If \(S\) is **finite**, then \(\theta(S)=1\) as well (the finite Boolean algebra generated by \(S\) is automatically closed under countable unions).

- **Dependence on \(|X|\):** The bound \(\theta(S)\le\omega_1\) does **not** depend on \(|X|\). Moreover, if \(|X|\ge|\mathbb R|\), you can transfer the Borel example to \(X\) via a bijection, so there exist \(S\subseteq\mathcal P(X)\) with \(\theta(S)=\omega_1\). (If \(|X|<|\mathbb R|\) but uncountable, there is still no general relation tying \(\theta(S)\) to \(|X|\); you can make \(\theta(S)\) small or large by how you choose \(S\).)

**Bottom line on “number of inductive steps”:**
- There is a **universal ceiling**: never more than \(\omega_1\) stages are needed.
- There is **no nontrivial universal floor**: depending on \(S\), the process may stabilize immediately (\(\theta=1\)) or require the full \(\omega_1\) alternation of countable unions and complements.
- Crucially, \(\theta(S)\) is driven by the **structural complexity** of \(S\) (how its sets interact under the σ–operations), not by the bare cardinalities \(|X|\) or \(|S|\).

---

## Size bound (cardinality of \(\sigma(S)\))

Every member of \(\sigma(S)\) can be described by a **countable code**: a well-founded countable tree whose leaves are labelled by members of \(S\) and whose internal nodes are either “complement” or “countable union”. Hence
\[
|\sigma(S)| \;\le\; (|S|+\aleph_0)^{\aleph_0}.
\]
In particular, if \(S\) is countable then \(|\sigma(S)|\le 2^{\aleph_0}\) (at most continuum), regardless of \(|X|\).

---

### Quick checklist

- Construction: \(\mathcal F_0=S\cup\{\varnothing,X\}\); \(\mathcal F_{\alpha+1} = \mathcal F_\alpha\cup\{A^c:A\in\mathcal F_\alpha\}\cup\{\bigcup_n A_n:A_n\in\mathcal F_\alpha\}\); \(\mathcal F_\lambda=\bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}\mathcal F_\beta\).  
- Output: \(\sigma(S)=\bigcup_{\alpha<\omega_1}\mathcal F_\alpha\).  
- Bounds: Always \(\theta(S)\le\omega_1\); \(\theta(S)\) can be \(1\), any countable ordinal, or \(\omega_1\), independent of \(|X|\) or \(|S|\).  
- Size: \(|\sigma(S)|\le(|S|+\aleph_0)^{\aleph_0}\).

Your intuition is on the right track, but let me pin it down precisely and generalize it cleanly.

# General schema

Fix an infinite cardinal \(\kappa\). Call \(\sigma_\kappa\)-**algebra** the least family of subsets of \(X\) that contains \(S\) and is closed under **complements** and **unions of size \(\le \kappa\)** (hence also intersections of size \(\le \kappa\) by De Morgan).  (In standard terminology: a \(\kappa\)-**complete Boolean algebra**.)

Define \((\mathcal F_\alpha)_{\alpha}\) by transfinite recursion:

- \(\mathcal F_0:=S\cup\{\varnothing,X\}\).
- \(\mathcal F_{\alpha+1}\) = the closure of \(\mathcal F_\alpha\) under complements and unions of \(\le \kappa\) many members of \(\mathcal F_\alpha\).
- \(\mathcal F_\lambda:=\bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}\mathcal F_\beta\) for limit \(\lambda\).

Then set
\[
\sigma_\kappa(S)\ :=\ \bigcup_{\alpha<\kappa^+}\mathcal F_\alpha.
\]

## Why \(\kappa^+\) stages suffice (and are optimal in general)

1) **Sufficiency.** Let \(|I|\le\kappa\) and \(A_i\in \bigcup_{\alpha<\kappa^+}\mathcal F_\alpha\). Pick \(\alpha_i<\kappa^+\) with \(A_i\in\mathcal F_{\alpha_i}\). Since \(|I|\le\kappa\) and \(\kappa^+\) is **regular** (in ZFC), \(\alpha:=\sup_{i\in I}\alpha_i<\kappa^+\). By construction,
\(\bigcup_{i\in I}A_i\in \mathcal F_{\alpha+1}\subseteq \bigcup_{\beta<\kappa^+}\mathcal F_\beta\).
Closure under complement is immediate at successors. Hence \(\bigcup_{\alpha<\kappa^+}\mathcal F_\alpha\) is a \(\sigma_\kappa\)-algebra containing \(S\), and by minimality of the construction it equals \(\sigma_\kappa(S)\).

2) **Sharpness.** In general you **cannot** stop earlier: for suitable \(X\) and \(S\) the hierarchy is strict at every level \(\alpha<\kappa^+\).
A standard witness is the **\(\kappa\)-Borel hierarchy** on \(2^\kappa\) (or \(\kappa^\kappa\)) where \(S\) is the clopen cylinder sets: \(\Sigma^0_\alpha(\kappa)\subsetneq \Sigma^0_{\alpha+1}(\kappa)\) for all \(\alpha<\kappa^+\). Thus the full \(\kappa^+\) climb can be required.

---

# How this answers your \(\omega_1/\omega_2\) question

- The usual σ-algebra corresponds to \(\kappa=\omega\) (closure under **countable** unions). Our scheme says you may need up to \(\kappa^+=\omega_1\) stages—exactly what happens for the classical Borel hierarchy.

- If you define your “\(\sigma_1\)-algebra” to mean closure under **\(\le \omega_1\)** unions/intersections (and complements), then take \(\kappa=\omega_1\). The bound becomes \(\kappa^+=\omega_2\). **Yes**: in general the explicit inductive construction stabilizes only by stage \(\omega_2\), and examples exist where every \(\alpha<\omega_2\) adds genuinely new sets.

> Small disambiguation: if by “\(\omega_1\) unions” one meant **“<\(\omega_1\)”** (i.e., countable) rather than “\(\le\omega_1\)”, then you’re back to the ordinary σ-case and the bound is \(\omega_1\), not \(\omega_2\).

---

# Compact takeaways

- For unions/intersections of size \(\le\kappa\), you need at most **\(\kappa^+\)** many closure steps, and this is tight in general.
- The classical σ-case is the special case \(\kappa=\omega\Rightarrow\kappa^+=\omega_1\).
- Your proposed “\(\sigma_1\)-algebra” (closed under \(\le\omega_1\) unions) indeed lines up with **\(\omega_2\)** steps in the worst case.
